. It is known best for being the home of
whiskey, as well as for having the world's largest Icelandic-Canadian population.
You can get to Gimli by taking Hwy 9 from

.
You can get to Gimli by taking Hwy 8 or 7 from Winnipeg.
There is also a Greyhound bus stop in this city as well.
As Gimli is such a small town you can walk anywhere. The closer you get to the beach the harder parking is to find on hot weekends.

Anyone interested in aviation history might want a look at the former Air Force base, now the Gimli Industrial Park Airport about two km West of town. That is where the ""Gimli Glider" put down. That was an Air Canada 767 that ran out of fuel at 41,000 feet (12,500 m) in 1983, and glided to a safe landing at Gimli.
The public beachfront is lovely for barefoot sunset walks on the water.

value: content=Shopping in gimli is one of a kind. mostly boutique type store
content=Enjoy the Splash Park in Gimli Park

Gimli is home to a number of small shops along Main Street and First Avenue targeted toward visitors. Handmade jewelry, unique artwork, and other interesting items can be purchased in a range of prices.

value: content=Awesome home made Greek food! Best pizza! Large portions. Also has an ice cream  parlor inside. Right in the center of town by the beach. Service is suburb. American classics like fries and burgers also tasty! Can't miss!
content=Good Greek food, burgers, sandwiches and a they are known for their pickeral dinner. Also serves ice cream. Also licensed. Dine in and take out available. Parking near by.

Locals drink at Cronshaws Pub (known as the Gimli Grinder now) 
It's a chill place to party, to relax and to come together. Live music venue for all musicians who play for the love of the vibe.
